ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about phonological rules and processes, the abstract underlying structure of language, and how to analyze a phonological dataset.
Phonological analysis, the complete IPA, some common processes and how they interact, and syllabic structure.
How to analyze phonological data and formalize phonological rules
Amazing course - learn about IPA and speech sounds. Great class for cogsci majors.

My knowledge and insight to the IPA was greatly helped by taking this course, as well as linguistically getting to break down how to analyze language data and break it down into rules based off of various linguistical concepts.  It also gave me an insight into how to examine sounds linguistically.
I developed a solid background in the terminology and methods of phonology, which was super accessible even for non-linguistics majors.
Basic introduction to phonology (phonological rules w/ feature classes, multiple rules, morpheme alterations, abstractions, syllable structure, etc.)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I wish we had gone through more difficult and complicated datasets in class. The practice we did in class was usually significantly easier than the psets.

The class is really flexible. Professor Natalie is very understanding and gives you basically infinite time to complete each pset. This class is designed to maximize the enjoyability of the learning experience and minimize pressure, and it's really helpful.

However, the final project and the language squibs not being regularly checked creates no incentive for us to do anything during the semester. It would be better if the weekly reports can be mandatory.

Strengths: highly structured but not too demanding of a workload
Weaknesses: I personally have a harder time in flipped classroom courses and would prefer introductions to subjects by the professor themselves first. However this course was suited well to flipped classroom and was not as stressful as other flipped classroom environments I have been in.

Strengths: reasonable workload, good in-class handouts, Natalie and Sammy are so so lovely. Weaknesses: sometimes it felt like we were going over the same material for a little too long, didnt get to Optimality Theory, which I was looking forward to

Weakness = final paper scheduling is quite rushed. 
Strength = lots of help through the course.

This course is really well structured in that there is an overarching project you are working on and problem sets that help you figure out how to approach the problem set.  Lecture was always helpful to run through examples of the ideas present in the problem set, and it is always well taught and goes through a variety of examples.  I do think the flipped classroom approach sometimes has its limits, especially with some of the more complicated concepts that we had to tackle, but they usually did a good job going through the ideas in class by examples so it almost always worked out.

I really like how we're given problems to solve during the class, because it helps with the psets a lot. I wish there was a bit more lecture-style teaching just laying out the basics, to give us a refresher on the terminology in the textbook readings. The language sketch is a very cool project and allows students to take things in different directions based on their interests.

Strengths: extremely engaging, well-presented course material, office hours, great feedback from TA
Weaknesses: if any, professor disorganization (though this, apart from on one frustrating occasion during finals week, did not significantly impact the course). grading system was sometimes frustrating, but written feedback was good and the system did at least help me get over some of my perfectionism, which actually ended up making the class less stressful (i.e. if you did everything correctly, you were given a 90%; nondescript "above and beyond" points were hard to earn/there were no real "guidelines" for earning them, and trying purposefully to earn them was both often unsuccessful did not always help with my learning)

This was a very well-organized course that covered a good amount of material. At times, it was hard to connect the reading to the problem sets in class (and Oden was not very easy to navigate) so I think having some sort of cumulative resource available for when students are working on the homework would be very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who is interested in language and who thinks in a very analytical/logical way. This class was a cool intersection of language-oriented content and mathematical thinking.

As a more syntax-heavy person, I can't say I enjoyed this class maximally. However, it gives a really nice taste of phonology and linguistics in general. You have no choice as a ling major :) For non-ling majors, do take it if you want to take a serious look at something you may take for granted.

I would recommend this course as someone who had never taken a linguistics course but found the subject of linguistics to be very intriguing and interesting. I had no idea what phonology was, but found that Prof Weber is highly engaging and made class time very enjoyable. I found that I was very interested in the class and would invest a lot of time in the class. 
tldr, Would recommend this class for someone looking to see if they truly linguistics but may not want a broad overview class such as Intro to Linguistics
Yes
If you are interested in Linguistics, definitely.  Its a really good class and very rewarding to go through.
Yes. Even for non-linguistics majors, Phonology I can be a fascinating introduction to linguistics. Phonology is a really cool field and I think the language sketch is a good hands-on project.
I would definitely recommend this course to other students! Course material was extremely engaging, especially for people interested in linguistics and/or math and other theoretical STEM subjects.

I would absolutely recommend this class to anyone who is remotely interested in linguistics. It provides a fantastic introduction/base and also introduces a number of topics (such as morphology or opacity) which can be further studied in other classes.
I recommend this course to linguistics majors or people interested in linguistics.
